Award.AwardTitle: Testing Models for the Origin of 186Os/188Os and 187Os/188Os Isotope Variations in the Mantle: Core Signal, Recycled Components, or Intra-mantle Differentiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to determine the physical and chemical process(es) responsible for generating variations in the osmium isotopic compositions of mantle-derived rocks. Previous studies havesuggested that some osmium isotope variations in lavas from Hawaii and Gorgona may reflect chemical interaction between the Earth?s mantle and core. If confirmed, this would have wide ranging implications for the chemical and thermal evolution of Earth?s interior. Testing this hypothesis through detailed study is therefore of high importance for the geologic community. Osmium isotopes are affected by the radioactive decay of rhenium and platinum, and so osmium isotope variations in geologic materials reflect long-term fractionation of the platinum/osmium and rhenium/osmium ratios in different portions of the Earth's interior. Several different processes in addition to core/mantle interaction can affect the osmium isotope compositions of different mantle reservoirs. These processes include recycling of oceanic crust and sediments into the mantle through plate tectonics, ancient mantle melting and melt extraction, and melting of distinct rock types in the mantle during melt generation today. Therefore, osmium isotope variations can provide important constraints on several geologic processes that have helped shape the chemical and physical evolution of Earth?s interior, but only if the different mechanisms for generating these isotopic variations can be distinguished.

This study will examine correlations between Osmium isotopes and other geochemical tracers in lavas from Hawaii and Gorgona Island, thought to be related to deep-seated mantle plumes, and in several suites of mantle-derived peridotites that span a range in composition. These analyses will allow the supported researchers to test and confirm or refute several hypotheses that have been proposed to explain unusual enrichments in 186Os (an isotope generated by the decay of 190Pt) in some plume-derived lavas. By combining high-precision 186Os/188Os data with complementary isotopic, major, and trace element data, the supported research will test several proposed mechanisms for generation of elevated 186Os/188Os ratios in mantle materials. The selected lava suites are chosen because they either have been reported to possess elevated 186Os/188Os in earlier studies (Hawaiian Islands, Gorgona), or because they possess geochemical characteristics that suggest a significant role for pyroxenite or eclogite melting in their generation (Australs HIMU lavas). The peridotite samples will help constrain the long-term coupling (or lack thereof) between Pt/Os and Re/Os ratios in the upper mantle, and illuminate the role that melt depletion plays in the 190Pt-186Os evolution of the upper mantle. Combined, this study will place stronger constraints on the different models proposed for the origin of Pt/Os fractionation and 186Os/188Os variation in the mantle than is currently possible, thereby addressing an important and longstanding controversy in the Geological Sciences and increasing the utility of the 190Pt-186Os decay system in future geochemical studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Naturally occurring radioactive decay systems are powerful tools in the Geosciences for studying the long-term evolution of the Earth’s surface and interior. This study examined isotopic variations in the platinum-group element osmium (Os) generated by the decay of radioactive isotopes of rhenium (Re) and platinum (Pt) in order to examine a number of fundamental questions related to Earth’s formation 4.5 billion years ago as well as the subsequent evolution of its mantle and continental crust. Platinum group elements such as Os are powerful tools for studying processes related to Earth’s formation from the solar nebula and subsequent differentiation into core, mantle, and crust due to the fact that osmium strongly partitions into metal and sulfide phases instead of rock-forming silicate mineral, and is therefore strongly concentrated in Earth’s core relative to the mantle. We examine very small variations in the ratio of Os isotopes generated by the decay of Pt and Re in order to constrain long-term variations in Pt/Os and Re/Os in different portions of the Earth. This research had several significant outcomes:

 

1)    Because the isotopic variations we sought to measure were extremely small, we developed an improved technique for measuring these variations using thermal ionization mass spectrometry. Our improved technique can be used for other studies involving Os isotopes and can be extrapolated to other isotopic systems as well.

2)    We were able to more tightly constrain the mantle’s initial Pt/Os ratio than previous studies, and shoed that the Pt/Os ratio closely matches that on primitive meteorites called chondrites, broadly believed to represent the basic “building blocks” for Earth’s formation from the solar nebula. This result supports a long-standing hypothesis that the Earth accreted a “late veneer” of chondritic material AFTER it differentiated into a metal core and silicate mantle. However, we also suggest that minor core formation due to segregation of metal or sulfide phases may have occurred contemporaneously with the addition of the late veneer.

3)    By examining the degree of variation in Os isotopes and Pt/Os and Re/Os ratios in mantle samples, we were able to constrain the timescale for mantle mixing and homogenization. This mixing timescale is a function of the style and speed of mantle convection, which ultimately drives plate tectonic process such as mountain building and growth of the continental crust. Our results suggest a mixing timescale greater than one billion years, which is consistent with mixing models that presume the mantle convects as a whole, rather than in separate upper and lower mantle layers.

4)    Previous studies had reported elevated levels of an isotope of Os generated by the decay of Pt in a number of ocean island basalts, thought to derive from deep-seated mantle plumes. These studies suggested this enrichment could reflect a signature of core/mantle interaction. We examined additional samples from these same localities using our improved analytical technique. None of our analyses revealed an unambiguous enrichment signature. In addition, we showed that the measured Pt/Os ratios of the samples previously reported to have this enrichment were not high enough to generate the enrichment over reasonable timescales. We argue that the enrichments are either rare in the source of ocean island basalts or that the previous reported enrichments are the result of undetected analytical problems. If the enrichments do exist, they are unlikely to be the result of core/mantle interaction.

5)    We examined Os-isotopes in different types of industrial steel as a way of indirectly constraining the isotopic composition of the main components used in steel manufacture – iron ore, coke derived from coal, and chromites. These components ultimately derive from the continental crust (coke and iron ore) or mantle (chromites) and so estimation of the Os-isotope compositions of these components allowed us to constrain the long-term Pt/Os and Re/Os evolution of the crust. Our results revealed that the long-term Pt/Os ratio of iron ore and coal is similar to that of the mantle. This is surprising because previous estimates of bulk continental crust suggest it is enriched in Pt relative to Os. We suggest that weathering processes, which are involved indirectly in the generation of the reservoirs that produce coal and iron ore, result in fractionation of Pt from Os in the weathered material. This fractionation is linked to the variable solubility of Pt and Os, which are controlled in part by the presence of oxygen in Earth’s atmosphere.

 

In addition to the above scientific results, this project supported the education of PhD student Rudra Chatterjee, who graduated in 2016. Dr. Chatterjee is currently employed as a research scientist in the United States. Thus, this project has contributed to the maintenance of a technically skilled US labor force.
